items.title: Israel Holidays Performance Issue
items.body:
While integrating the workalendar library to some of our projects we detected some performance issues with the Israel calendar.

We are using the `is_holiday` method, and while looking into the Israel code I saw that the way to retrieve the Israel holidays list is inefficient, since it is checking every day in a year instead of using some holidays list.

items.title: Flag original dates for observed days
items.body:
When an observed day (i.e. holidays that are moved because they are on a weekend) is returned would it possible to flag what the original date was rather than relying on a string suffix? 

Also, in some locations when a holiday falls on a weekend, it is moved to a weekday as an observed day. In some of these locations only the observed day is considered a holiday whereas in others both the observed and original days are considered holidays. This is an important distinction in some jurisdictions. 

Is there any chance of supporting an additional flag against observed holidays that indicate the original day is or isn't a holiday?

items.title: Missing days and not relevant days in the Israeli calendar
items.body:
There are two issues in the Israeli calendar:
* Working days holidays are confused with non-working days holidays (Purim, Hol Hamoed Sukkot, Gdalia Fast)
* The holidays' eves are missing. People in Israel usually won't work on a holiday eve, and if they will it will be only until noonish.

see the holidays here (the non-working holidays are only those with a blank observance):
https://www.qppstudio.net/publicholidays2020/israel.htm

so for 2020 we should remove:
date(2020, 9, 21),  # Gdalia Fast
date(2020, 3, 10),  # Purim
date(2020, 3, 11),  # Purim
date(2020, 10, 4),  # Hol Hamoed Sukkot
date(2020, 10, 5),  # Hol Hamoed Sukkot
date(2020, 10, 6),  # Hol Hamoed Sukkot
date(2020, 10, 7),  # Hol Hamoed Sukkot
date(2020, 10, 8),  # Hol Hamoed Sukkot

and add:
date(2020, 9, 18),  # Rosh Hashana Eve
date(2020, 9, 27),  # Kippur Eve
date(2020, 10, 2),  # Sukot A Eve
date(2020, 10, 9),  # Sukot B Eve
date(2020, 4, 8),  # Pesach A Eve
date(2020, 4, 14),  # Pesach B Eve
date(2020, 4, 28),  # Independence Day Eve
date(2020, 5, 28),  # Shavuot Eve

items.title: Issue with USA Thanksgiving Friday (Blackfriday) calculation
items.body:
USA core.py has an issue where Thanksgiving Friday is computed as 4th Friday of November (drawing a parallel from US Thanksgiving which falls on 4th Thursday of November).
While the logic works most of the time, it fails if 1st Nov happens to be a Friday.
Ideally, Thanksgiving Friday should be calculated as a day after Thanksgiving, which is also the definition.
version - master (7.2.0.dev0)
_Though I believe it is platform independent._
I have tried it on Mac OS 10.13 with Python 3.6.5

items.title: Geneva Calendar
items.body:
The calendar in Geneva is the same as the Swiss calendar, with the following exceptions:
* Berchtold's day is not celebrated (2.1)
* They celebrate two additional holidays:
   * Jeûne genevois or Genevan Fast: Thursday following the first Sunday of September
   * Creation of the Geneva Republic: Celebrated on the 31.12

I will create a PR soon.

items.title: Global registry API - items() interface
items.body:
This is subtask of #375

* The ``items()`` method would be renamed into ``get_calendars``. In a near future, this ``items`` method would change its purpose and would return an iterator instead of the expected dictionary.
* ``get_calendars()`` would return the full list of calendars.
* ``get_calendars([list of codes...])`` would return a dictionary of calendars whose codes are in the registry. Unkown codes would be skipped. Sub-regions codes would be allowed (e.g.: ``get_calendars(['CA-AB', 'AU-NT'])`` would return the Canada Alberta & Australia Northern Territory calendars)
* ``get_calendars([list of codes...], include_subregions=True)`` same as above, except that you would get also subregions when they exist.

### Task list

* extensive testing,
* changes in the iso-register.md documentation
* DeprecationWarnings - how to handle this in versionning?

items.title: Beta-testing a ephem-less version of workalendar
items.body:
# Rationale

1. (Py)Ephem is (or... *was*) a Python package to compute astronomical ephemeris, used in some calendars that depend on the date of the [equinoxes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equinox) or [solar terms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_term),
2. The development of `ephem` has stopped a few years ago ; this presents a risk of bugs and/or miscalculations in the future,
3. `ephem` requires Python-Dev headers in order to link to libastro and compilation, which is not easy on end-user platforms (especially Windows) or even on servers where compilers are forbidden,
4. [Skyfield](https://rhodesmill.org/skyfield/) is the successor of `ephem` and it requires no compilation, so it's allegedly easier to install.

## Current status

Workalendar is using ephem.
There's a Release Candidate available on the **Test PyPI** that doesn't include `ephem` but would use `skyfield` for astronomical calculations.
Anybody with a Python-ready Windows machine could now help us test and validate this RC.
Or anyone with a Linux machine that doesn't include python headers and compilers, also.

You can find a procedure below. If you volounteer, please follow it and report its result in the comments.

----

# Preparation

In your further comments, please mention:

* your OS and version,
* Your python version,
* Your version of virtualenv,
* Any other specific information you may think is appropriate (*how many coffee cups did you have before the test*, for example)

Note: the ``/tmp`` directory is given as an example, it means that you may trash your virtualenv after the test.

## Is the current workalendar install failing?

```sh
# Create a virtualenv
cd /tmp
virtualenv venv1  # Python 2? Python 3? not sure
source venv1/bin/activate
# Try either one of the following and give us the results
pip install --no-binary :all: workalendar
pip install workalendar
```


## Is the release candidate a right candidate?

```sh
# Create a virtualenv
cd /tmp
virtualenv venv  # Python 2? Python 3? not sure
source venv/bin/activate
# Install workalendar requirements from canonical PyPI
pip install skyfield skyfield-data python-dateutil lunardate pytz pyCalverter pyluach
# Install workalendar RC
pip install --index-url https://test.pypi.org/simple/ workalendar
```

In case of failure, please give us the error messages.
In case of success, please give us the result of ``pip freeze -l``

# Is it working?

Open a Python Shell.

## The simple test

```python
>>> from workalendar.europe import France
>>> cal = France()
>>> cal.holidays(2019)
[(datetime.date(2019, 1, 1), 'New year'), (datetime.date(2019, 4, 22), 'Easter Monday'), (datetime.date(2019, 5, 1), 'Labour Day'), (datetime.date(2019, 5, 8), 'Victory in Europe Day'), (datetime.date(2019, 5, 30), 'Ascension Thursday'), (datetime.date(2019, 6, 10), 'Whit Monday'), (datetime.date(2019, 7, 14), 'Bastille Day'), (datetime.date(2019, 8, 15), 'Assumption of Mary to Heaven'), (datetime.date(2019, 11, 1), 'All Saints Day'), (datetime.date(2019, 11, 11), 'Armistice Day'), (datetime.date(2019, 12, 25), 'Christmas Day')]
```

## The Astronomical calendar test

```python
>>> from workalendar.asia import Taiwan
>>> cal = Taiwan()
>>> cal.holidays(2019)
[(datetime.date(2019, 1, 1), 'New year'), (datetime.date(2019, 2, 4), "Chinese New Year's eve"), (datetime.date(2019, 2, 5), 'Chinese New Year'), (datetime.date(2019, 2, 6), 'Chinese New Year (2nd day)'), (datetime.date(2019, 2, 7), 'Chinese New Year (3rd day)'), (datetime.date(2019, 2, 28), '228 Peace Memorial Day'), (datetime.date(2019, 4, 4), "Combination of Women's Day and Children's Day"), (datetime.date(2019, 4, 5), 'Qingming Festival'), (datetime.date(2019, 6, 7), 'Dragon Boat Festival'), (datetime.date(2019, 9, 13), 'Mid-Autumn Festival'), (datetime.date(2019, 10, 10), 'National Day/Double Tenth Day')]
```

items.title: Problem with duration calculation
items.body:
Hello,

First of all, thank you for developping such a library, it's really useful in some situations...

I'm currently playing with it and I think I found an issue that can be bothering... ^^

I'm using the `calendar.get_working_days_delta` method, and I found an interesting problem (maybe not a bug? You tell me :) )

Steps:
*  I want to compute working days between two following dates (let's say `31/12/2018 00:01` and `01/01/2019 19:03`) and the result is not correct... I should have 1 working day (and so in my case 11hours of working time, but not the point here) but I actually get 0 working days...

What is actually working:
*  I want to compute working days between two following dates (let's say `01/01/2019 00:01` and `02/01/2019`) and here the result is ok, I'm having 1 working day (and so in my case 11 hours of working time, but again not the point here).

Environment:
*  `python3.7.4`
*  `workalendar==5.0.3` (Pypi)

How to reproduce the situation:
```python
from dateutil.parser import parse
from workalendar.europe import France

cal = France()

# First use case: it's ok, everything is fine
d_1 = parse('01/01/2019 00:01', dayfirst=True)
d_2 = parse('02/01/2019 19:01', dayfirst=True)

print(f'{d_1} is a working day? {cal.is_working_day(d_1)}')
print(f'{d_2} is a working day? {cal.is_working_day(d_2)}')
print(f'Number of working days between: {cal.get_working_days_delta(d_1, d_2)}')

# Second use case: not ok
d_1 = parse('31/12/2018 00:01', dayfirst=True)
d_2 = parse('01/01/2019 19:01', dayfirst=True)

print(f'{d_1} is a working day? {cal.is_working_day(d_1)}')
print(f'{d_2} is a working day? {cal.is_working_day(d_2)}')
print(f'Number of working days between: {cal.get_working_days_delta(d_1, d_2)}')
```

Output:
```
2019-01-01 00:01:00 is a working day? False
2019-01-02 19:01:00 is a working day? True
Number of working days between: 1

2018-12-31 00:01:00 is a working day? True
2019-01-01 19:01:00 is a working day? False
Number of working days between: 0
```

items.title: Global registry API
items.body:
The current state of the global registry annoys me a bit.

1. it returns ``OrderedDict``s instead of plain built-in ``dict``s for no apparent reasons.
2. It could mimic a dictionary, but instead it has a sub-dictionary, called ``region_registry``, that somehow "hides" the "true" registry (i.e. the full list of calendars registered).
3. It has an ``items()`` method that doesn't behave like the standard ``items()`` method of a dictionary-like object. It requires an argument to search for items.
4. It doesn't have a ``get()`` method, but it's named ``get_calendar_class()``.

Each point could lead to a series of changes in its API. Considering that I've already warned workalendar users that the registry return type would change, I'd like to make a case on each of the above points.

## 1 - ``dict``s instead of ``OrderedDict``s

The branch is already ready, no big deal.

## 2 & 3 & 4 - dictionary interface

Here are the changes I envision:

* ``items()`` would return the full list of calendars.
* ``items([list of codes...])`` would return a dictionary of calendars whose codes are in the registry. Unkown codes would be skipped. Sub-regions codes would be allowed (e.g.: ``items(['CA-AB', 'AU-NT'])`` would return the Canada Alberta & Australia Northern Territory calendars)
* ``items([list of codes...], include_subregions=True)`` same as above, except that you would get also subregions when they exist.
* ``get_calendar_class()`` would be aliased to ``get()``, deprecated and then removed.

The whole process can be handled via deprecation warnings and careful versionning. It could also be done in one shot, switching from the 5.x series to 6.0.

## Beyond

Thinking out loud, not a priority, and maybe overkill:

Maybe this registry could also be an object that inherits from ``dict()`` objects? Or maybe make it an ``Iterable`` to ease map/filter operations?

----

## Task list

* [x] ``dict``s instead of ``OrderedDict``s #391
* [x] Deprecate `items()` in favor of `get_calendars()` #403
* [x] Allow `get_calendars()` to give empty `region_codes` argument, to retrieve the full data #403
* [x] Remove the `registry.items()` method #491
* [x] Alias `get_calendar_class` into `get()` #418
* [x] Completely drop `registry.get_calendar_class` method #495

items.title: Possibility to install a subset of countries
items.body:
Hello,

First of all, thank you for creating this amazing library! 👍 

This is not an issue, it's just an idea/feature request. We are deploying our Python applications in AWS lambdas, lambdas are all well and good but they have their limitations as well, and one them is the total package size which is limited to 50 MB limit. We tried to use Workalendar as one of our dependencies but it, unfortunately, blew up our 50 MB limit. There are ways to work around it, we are aware of that, but those workarounds also involve an increase in the lambda cold start time.

Our use case is very simple: we just need to know the working days here in The Netherlands. Therefore we "fixed" our issue by just extracting the Dutch working days into a vendor library. But I was wondering that this must be a very common use case for other people as well, I mean, I believe that most people just need to know the working days of their own country or maybe a few extra ones. Therefore, most of the code (and dependencies like ephem and lunardate) being installed is just not being used at all. I think that #302 is related to this

I think that this could be solved by splitting this library into several, one core library plus several extra ones for each country. The installation could be done by using the Setuptools `extra_requires`, e.g.:

```python
setup(
    name="workalendar",
    ...
    extras_require={
        'netherlands':  ["workalendar-netherlands"],
        'germany':  ["workalendar-germany"],
        'europe':  ["workalendar-netherlands", "workalendar-germany", ...],
        ...
        'islamic':  [...],
        'all':  [...],
    }
)
```

One drawback of this approach is that the virtualenv might get convoluted for people that require many countries. This might be a problem because many people are doing `pip freeze > requirements.txt`. One way to work around this would be to write some scripts that automatically vendorize the dependencies and publish pre-built packages to PyPI. Anyway, I understand that this is a huge change to the project, so I think it is probably unfeasible?

Thanks!

items.title: `is_holiday` function doesn't return correct result when pandas `Timestamp` is passed.
items.body:
The `is_holiday` function expects a `datetime.datetime` format. However, it doesn't raise any error when a pandas `Timestamp` is passed (https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/version/0.23.4/generated/pandas.Timestamp.html). 

Here is a code example (`workalendar` version '3.1.1'):  

```
from workalendar import europe
import pandas as pd
import datetime


fr = europe.France()
# Should be True and returns True
print(fr.is_holiday(datetime.datetime(2017, 1, 1)))
# Should be True but returns False
print(fr.is_holiday(pd.to_datetime("2017-1-1")))
# To fix this, use the `to_pydatetime` method
print(fr.is_holiday(pd.to_datetime("2017-1-1").to_pydatetime()))

```
I expect the library to raise an error when the passed input isn't of type `datetime.datetime`.
What are your thoughts? 
Thanks in advance. :)

items.title: Avoid circular import in registry
items.body:
In current version (`3.0.0`) there is a circular import involving `registry.py` which makes interpreter to fully load the whole library everytime a calendar is used.

The circular may be summarized like this: `registry.py` -> `<continent-module>` -> `<country-cal>.py` -> `registry.py`. This however works thanks to how interpreters read the code (ie: `iso_register` decorator is defined _before_ importing every country in `registry.py`, so it works).

To test this try:
```
# see https://docs.python.org/3.5/library/trace.html
from trace import Trace
tracer = Trace() 
# make run a simple import for a single country
tracer.run('from workalendar.europe.italy import Italy')
res = tracer.results() 
# print results
res.write_results(coverdir='.', summary=True)
```

You will see that to load a single calendar the whole library was loaded. This may be fine in some cases, but its a waste of execution time and memory.

A kind of lazy registry may perform better. However some kind of mapping and a bit of logic are required for this to be accomplished.

def get_working_days_delta(begin, end):

items.title: Bug/feature in find_following_working_day
items.body:
find_following_working_day returns the next non-weekend day, but not necessarily the next working day.

E.g. if a Sunday and a Monday are public holidays (assuming SAT/SUN weekend), and one wants to roll the Sunday to the next working day then it should return Tuesday.  Instead it returns Monday.

Since this function is often used for determining which days are holidays, it is non-trivial to just incorporate the holiday calendar as you get a chicken and egg situation (you can't check the holiday calendar when trying to calculate the holiday calendar).

items.title: get_weekend_days on base Calendar class
items.body:
Hi,

get_weekend_days raises a NotImplementedError on the base class, but a sensible default could be provided using the method from WesternCalendar (which returns self.WEEKEND_DAYS).

For example, Qatar has WEEKEND_DAYS correctly set to (FRI, SAT) - but fails since it doesn't derive from WesternCalendar.  Obviously one could copy the WesternCalendar implementation across, but surely something like:

```
if self.WEEKEND_DAYS:
     return self.WEEKEND_DAYS
else:
    raise NotImplementedError
```

on the base class makes more sense (and then remove the WesternCalendar method)?

I'm happy to throw out a PR if this makes sense.

items.title: Is France calendar production-ready?
items.body:
Hi there.

Probably not the best place to ask, but I'm really interrested in integrating this library into a business codebase. I already saw people recommending using it (meaning that they find it suitable for production use already). I was just wondering whether, despite the disclaimer in the README, at least the France calendar was already production-ready in some "simple" cases. Of course, if I encounter any bug, I'd be happy to contribute and I'm not expecting something incredibly stable or well-documented; I just don't want to dive into an early pre-alpha project with dozens of known and unresolved bugs, or with major breaking-changes and refactorings to come. My own business code will be tested thoroughly anyways, and impacts of bugs on this library should be moderate (we'll not pay salaries using this library, nor put hudge load into it. Nobody will be injured in case of trouble :p ).

Just to be clear, the precise question is: this library is some years-old, people seem to already be using it in production with great satisfaction, the project is active and well maintained, I can't find any major issue in the issue tracker, calendars are looking accurate, what makes you say this library is "barely beta"?

Thank you in advance for the enlightenment.
Regards,
Gilbs

items.title: Germany 2017: Reformation Day is valid in all states
items.body:
The Reformation Day in the next year 2017 is public holiday in whole Germany. 
In the other years it is valid only in Brandenburg, MecklenburgVorpommern, Saxony, SaxonyAnhalt, Thuringia (as it is defined now correctly).
https://www.welt.de/regionales/nrw/article143064981/Reformationstag-2017-wird-auch-in-NRW-ein-Feiertag.html

>>> from workalendar.asia import Japan
